options.option_text: YES
NO

questions.question_text_1: Suppose that Nita’s utility function is given by u(I) = (10I)0.5 , where I represents annual income in thousands of dollars. Suppose that Nita is currently earning an income of $40,000 (I = 40) and can earn that income next year with certainty. She is offered a chance to take a new job that offers a 0.6 probability of earning $44,000 and a 0.4 probability of earning $33,000.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Suppose that Nita’s utility function is given by u(I) = (10I)0.5 , where I represents annual income in thousands of dollars. Suppose that Nita is currently earning an income of $40,000 (I = 40) and can earn that income next year with certainty. She is offered a chance to take a new job that offers a 0.6 probability of earning $44,000 and a 0.4 probability of earning $33,000.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Nita’s risk preferences are
question_texts: Nita’s risk preferences are

options.option_text: Risk averse
Risk loving
Risk neutral
Cannot be determined

questions.question_text_1: Suppose a second firm enters the market. Let Q1 be the output of the first firm and Q2 be the output of the second. Market demand is now given by Q1 + Q2 = 53 – P. Assuming that this second firm has the same costs as the first and the firms are competing as per the Cournot competition, find out the equilibrium quantity for each firm, equilibrium price and profit of each firm(π1,π2).  Q1*= ___________

questions.question_text_1: Mohan quits his IT job, where he was earning a salary of ₹500,000 per year, to start his own restaurant business in a building that he owns and was previously renting out for ₹240,000 per year. In his first year of business, he has the following expenses: salary paid to himself, ₹400,000; rent, ₹0; other expenses, ₹250,000.   Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Mohan quits his IT job, where he was earning a salary of ₹500,000 per year, to start his own restaurant business in a building that he owns and was previously renting out for ₹240,000 per year. questions.question_text_1: India currently imports all of its palm oil. The annual demand for palm oil by Indian consumers is given by the demand curve Q=2500-2P, where Q is quantity of palm oil in thousand litres and P is market price in INR per litre. World producers can harvest and ship palm oil to Indian distributors at a constant marginal cost (=average cost) of INR 100 and Indian distributors can distribute it at a cost of INR 25 per litre. Consider market for palm oil to be competitive. Indian government is considering a tariff on palm oil import of INR 25 per litre. Answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: India currently imports all of its palm oil. The annual demand for palm oil by Indian consumers is given by the demand curve Q=2500-2P, where Q is quantity of palm oil in thousand litres and P is market price in INR per litre. World producers can harvest and ship palm oil to Indian distributors at a constant marginal cost (=average cost) of INR 100 and Indian distributors can distribute it at a cost of INR 25 per litre. Consider market for palm oil to be competitive. Indian government is considering a tariff on palm oil import of INR 25 per litre. Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: If there is no tariff, what is the quantity demanded (in thousand litres)______________
question_texts: If there is no tariff, what is the quantity demanded (in thousand litres)______________

parent_question.question_text_1: India currently imports all of its palm oil. The annual demand for palm oil by Indian consumers is given by the demand curve Q=2500-2P, where Q is quantity of palm oil in thousand litres and P is market price in INR per litre. World producers can harvest and ship palm oil to Indian distributors at a constant marginal cost (=average cost) of INR 100 and Indian distributors can distribute it at a cost of INR 25 per litre. Consider market for palm oil to be competitive. Indian government is considering a tariff on palm oil import of INR 25 per litre. Answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: India currently imports all of its palm oil. The annual demand for palm oil by Indian consumers is given by the demand curve Q=2500-2P, where Q is quantity of palm oil in thousand litres and P is market price in INR per litre. World producers can harvest and ship palm oil to Indian distributors at a constant marginal cost (=average cost) of INR 100 and Indian distributors can distribute it at a cost of INR 25 per litre. Consider market for palm oil to be competitive. Indian government is considering a tariff on palm oil import of INR 25 per litre. Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Two used car dealerships compete side by side on a main road. The first, Hamid’s Cars, always sells high-quality cars that it carefully inspects and, if necessary, services. On average, it costs Hamid’s $8000 to buy and service each car that it sells. The second dealership, Latif’s Motors, always sells lower-quality cars. On average, it costs Latif’s only $5000 for each car that it sells. If consumers knew the quality of the used cars they were buying, they would pay $10,000 on average for Hamid’s cars and only $7000 on average for Latif’s cars.  Without more information, consumers do not know the quality of each dealership’s cars. In this case, they would figure that they have a 50-50 chance of ending up with a high quality car, and are thus willing to pay $8500 for a car.  Hamid has an idea: He will offer a bumper-to-bumper warranty for all cars he sells. He knows that a warranty lasting Y years will cost $500Y on average, and he also knows that if Latif tries to offer the same warranty, it will cost Latif $1000Y on average. Suppose Hamid offers a one-year warranty on all of the cars he sells.   Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Two used car dealerships compete side by side on a main road. The first, Hamid’s Cars, always sells high-quality cars that it carefully inspects and, if necessary, services. On average, it costs Hamid’s $8000 to buy and service each car that it sells. The second dealership, Latif’s Motors, always sells lower-quality cars. On average, it costs Latif’s only $5000 for each car that it sells. If consumers knew the quality of the used cars they were buying, they would pay $10,000 on average for Hamid’s cars and only $7000 on average for Latif’s cars.  Without more information, consumers do not know the quality of each dealership’s cars. In this case, they would figure that they have a 50-50 chance of ending up with a high quality car, and are thus willing to pay $8500 for a car.  Hamid has an idea: He will offer a bumper-to-bumper warranty for all cars he sells. He knows that a warranty lasting Y years will cost $500Y on average, and he also knows that if Latif tries to offer the same warranty, it will cost Latif $1000Y on average. Suppose Hamid offers a one-year warranty on all of the cars he sells.   Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: What is Latif’s profit (per car in $) if he does not offer a one-year warranty?_____________
question_texts: What is Latif’s profit (per car in $) if he does not offer a one-year warranty?_____________

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **Managerial Economics** exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Key Concepts**
### **1. Utility Theory & Risk Preferences**
- **Utility Function**: \( u(I) = (10I)^{0.5} \) (where \( I \) = income in thousands).
- **Expected Utility (EU)**:
  \[
  EU = \sum p_i \cdot u(I_i)
  \]
  - Compare EU of risky prospect vs. certain income to determine risk aversion/neutrality/loving.
- **Risk Aversion**:
  - If \( u(I) \) is concave (diminishing marginal utility), the individual is **risk-averse**.
  - **Certainty Equivalent (CE)**: The certain income that gives the same utility as a risky prospect.
  - **Risk Premium (RP)**: \( \text{RP} = \text{Expected Income} - \text{CE} \).
- **Insurance Willingness to Pay**:
  - Maximum premium = **Risk Premium** (difference between expected income and CE).

**Key Equations**:
- For Nita’s problem:
  \[
  u(40) = \sqrt{10 \times 40} = \sqrt{400} = 20
  \]
  \[
  EU_{\text{new job}} = 0.6 \cdot \sqrt{10 \times 44} + 0.4 \cdot \sqrt{10 \times 33} \approx 0.6 \times 20.98 + 0.4 \times 18.17 \approx 19.92
  \]
  - Since \( 19.92 < 20 \), Nita is **risk-averse** and **should not take the job**.
  - **Insurance Premium**: Solve \( u(I - \text{Premium}) = 19.92 \).

---

### **2. Monopoly & Oligopoly**
#### **A. Monopoly**
- **Demand Curve**: \( Q = 53 - P \) → \( P = 53 - Q \).
- **Total Revenue (TR)**: \( TR = P \cdot Q = (53 - Q)Q = 53Q - Q^2 \).
- **Marginal Revenue (MR)**: \( MR = \frac{d(TR)}{dQ} = 53 - 2Q \).
- **Profit Maximization**: Set \( MR = MC \).
  - Given \( MC = AC = 5 \):
    \[
    53 - 2Q = 5 \implies Q^* = 24, \quad P^* = 53 - 24 = 29
    \]
- **Profit**: \( \pi = TR - TC = (29 \times 24) - (5 \times 24) = 576 \).

#### **B. Cournot Duopoly**
- **Market Demand**: \( Q_1 + Q_2 = 53 - P \).
- **Reaction Functions**:
  - Firm 1’s profit: \( \pi_1 = (53 - Q_1 - Q_2 - 5)Q_1 \).
  - Maximize \( \pi_1 \): \( \frac{\partial \pi_1}{\partial Q_1} = 48 - 2Q_1 - Q_2 = 0 \).
  - Symmetric equilibrium: \( Q_1 = Q_2 = 16 \).
- **Equilibrium Price**: \( P = 53 - (16 + 16) = 21 \).
- **Profits**: \( \pi_1 = \pi_2 = (21 - 5) \times 16 = 256 \).

#### **C. Stackelberg Duopoly**
- **Leader (Firm 1)** moves first; **Follower (Firm 2)** responds.
- **Firm 2’s Reaction Function**: \( Q_2 = \frac{48 - Q_1}{2} \).
- **Firm 1’s Profit**:
  \[
  \pi_1 = (53 - Q_1 - Q_2 - 5)Q_1 = (48 - Q_1 - \frac{48 - Q_1}{2})Q_1
  \]
  - Solve \( \frac{d\pi_1}{dQ_1} = 0 \): \( Q_1^* = 24 \), \( Q_2^* = 12 \).
- **Price**: \( P = 53 - (24 + 12) = 17 \).
- **Profits**: \( \pi_1 = 288 \), \( \pi_2 = 144 \).

**Key Equations**:
- Monopoly: \( MR = MC \), \( \pi = (P - AC)Q \).
- Cournot: Solve \( \frac{\partial \pi_i}{\partial Q_i} = 0 \) simultaneously.
- Stackelberg: Substitute follower’s reaction into leader’s profit.

---

### **3. Cost Analysis**
- **Accounting Cost**: Explicit costs (e.g., salaries, rent, expenses).
  - Mohan’s accounting cost = ₹400,000 (salary) + ₹250,000 (other expenses) = **₹650,000**.
- **Economic Cost**: Accounting cost + **Opportunity Cost** (foregone salary + rent).
  - Mohan’s economic cost = ₹650,000 + ₹500,000 (salary) + ₹240,000 (rent) = **₹1,390,000** (Note: Answer key says ₹990,000; likely excludes salary as it’s already counted in accounting cost. Clarify with instructor.).
- **Opportunity Cost**: Value of the next best alternative (e.g., Mohan’s foregone salary and rent).

---

### **4. Tariffs & Trade**
- **Demand Curve**: \( Q = 2500 - 2P \).
- **Supply with Tariff**:
  - **World Cost**: ₹100 (production) + ₹25 (distribution) = ₹125.
  - **Tariff**: ₹25 → New cost = ₹150.
- **Equilibrium without Tariff**:
  - \( P = MC = 125 \), \( Q = 2500 - 2(125) = 2250 \).
- **Equilibrium with Tariff**:
  - \( P = 150 \), \( Q = 2500 - 2(150) = 2200 \).
- **Consumer Surplus (CS) Loss**:
  - \( \Delta CS = \frac{1}{2} \times (2250 - 2200) \times (150 - 125) = 6,250 \) (Note: Answer key says ₹55,625; likely calculates total CS change, not just the triangular loss. Use integral for precise CS.).
- **Tax Revenue**: \( \text{Tariff} \times Q = 25 \times 2200 = 55,000 \).
- **Deadweight Loss (DWL)**:
  - \( DWL = \frac{1}{2} \times (2250 - 2200) \times 25 = 625 \).
  - **Net Loss**: DWL is always a loss; no gain offsets it.

**Key Equations**:
- CS: \( \int_{Q_1}^{Q_2} P(Q) \, dQ \).
- Tax Revenue: \( t \times Q_{\text{new}} \).
- DWL: \( \frac{1}{2} \times \Delta Q \times t \).

---

### **5. Asymmetric Information**
#### **A. Adverse Selection**
- **Problem**: High-risk individuals (e.g., bad drivers) are more likely to buy insurance.
- **Solution**: Screening (e.g., driving records) or signaling (e.g., warranties).
- **Example**: Latif’s Motors sells low-quality cars; consumers cannot distinguish quality → **market for lemons**.

#### **B. Moral Hazard**
- **Problem**: Insured individuals take more risks (e.g., reckless driving).
- **Solution**: Monitor behavior or align incentives (e.g., deductibles).

#### **C. Signaling & Warranties**
- **Hamid’s Cars**: High-quality, warranty cost = ₹500Y.
- **Latif’s Motors**: Low-quality, warranty cost = ₹1000Y.
- **Equilibrium**:
  - If Hamid offers a warranty, Latif **cannot profitably mimic** (higher warranty cost).
  - **Separating Equilibrium**: Hamid signals quality with warranty; Latif does not.

**Key Takeaways**:
- Adverse selection → **hidden information**.
- Moral hazard → **hidden action**.
- Signaling → **credible communication of quality**.

---

### **6. Market Structures**
| **Market Type**       | **Key Features**                                                                 | **Profit Condition**                     |
|-----------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| **Monopoly**          | Single seller, price maker, barriers to entry.                                  | \( MR = MC \), \( P > MC \).             |
| **Cournot Duopoly**   | Firms choose quantity simultaneously; Nash equilibrium.                        | \( \frac{\partial \pi_i}{\partial Q_i} = 0 \). |
| **Stackelberg Duopoly** | Leader moves first; follower responds.                                       | Leader has first-mover advantage.       |
| **Monopolistic Competition** | Differentiated products, free entry/exit, \( P > MC \) in short run, \( P = AC \) in long run. | Zero economic profit in long run. |

---

### **7. Price Discrimination**
| **Degree** | **Description**                                                                 | **Example**                          |
|------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| **1st**    | Charge each consumer their **reservation price**.                            | Perfect personalization.             |
| **2nd**    | Quantity discounts (e.g., bulk pricing).                                       | "Buy 2, get 1 free."                |
| **3rd**    | Segment markets (e.g., student discounts).                                    | Airline tickets (business vs. economy). |

---

### **8. Production Functions**
| **Type**          | **Form**                     | **Key Feature**                          |
|-------------------|------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| **Cobb-Douglas**  | \( Q = AK^\alpha L^\beta \) | Constant elasticity of substitution.    |
| **Leontief**      | \( Q = \min(aK, bL) \)       | Fixed input ratios (no substitution).   |
| **Linear**        | \( Q = aK + bL \)            | Perfect substitutability (e.g., 3L = 1K). |

---

## **Key Equations Summary**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Utility**             | \( u(I) = (10I)^{0.5} \), \( EU = \sum p_i u(I_i) \)                       |
| **Risk Premium**        | \( RP = E[I] - CE \), where \( u(CE) = EU \)                              |
| **Monopoly**            | \( MR = 53 - 2Q \), \( MR = MC \), \( \pi = (P - AC)Q \)                   |
| **Cournot Duopoly**     | \( \frac{\partial \pi_i}{\partial Q_i} = 48 - 2Q_i - Q_j = 0 \)           |
| **Stackelberg**         | Leader: \( Q_1 = 24 \), Follower: \( Q_2 = \frac{48 - Q_1}{2} \)           |
| **Tariff**              | \( Q = 2500 - 2P \), \( CS = \int P(Q) \, dQ \), \( DWL = \frac{1}{2} \times \Delta Q \times t \) |
| **Accounting Cost**     | Explicit costs (salaries, rent, expenses).                                 |
| **Economic Cost**       | Accounting Cost + Opportunity Cost.                                        |
| **Adverse Selection**   | \( P_{\text{pool}} = \frac{P_{\text{high}} + P_{\text{low}}}{2} \)       |
